text:
Hi guys! Hope you're all really, really well. I'm 
going to give you the principles to make the best

risotto ever. The flavour that we're going to 
do is smoky bacon with sweet peas and gorgeous

crumbly goat cheese. And this is celebrating 
the fact that I've got my beautiful pans

made by Tefal, in John Lewis and partners right now. 
So first principle when making the perfect risotto

is actually the pan. It's a high sided pan. You've 
also got the quantities on the inside as well

so you know how much you're cooking and how much 
you're serving which is great. We also want a nice

lid for later on to go on top as well. So we've got 
that on a medium-high heat. I want to use half an

onion. So the Italians would call this the sofrito 
and the sofrito is the base of any soup or stew

or risotto. Okay so we've got the onions nice and 
fine which is lovely. The next part of the sofrito

is celery and if you can get some celery heart, 
that is my favourite bit. And you basically do the

same thing as the onion. We'll just keep chopping 
until it's nice and fine. So that's the base

done. Then we're going to begin with flavour, smoked 
pancetta or bacon. So four rashers is all you need

and then I just want to finely slice it into 
little matchsticks. So to help it along I'm

going to do two things. I'm going to add a little 
bit of olive oil then we're going to go in with

the pancetta or smoky bacon. Then here we've got 
some thyme. So just get yourself a little wadge

of those lovely tender leaves, just rip them off. 
No more than that, right. That's all you need. Then

I'll just finely slice it a little bit and that 
little bit of thyme will make all the difference.

We're going to render off this bacon. Then we're 
going to go in with our sofrito, the onions

and the celery. The beautiful smoky bacon, we're 
gonna soften that off, right and we're gonna let

it go nice and sweet. So just like 3 or 4
minutes on a fairly high heat and as that starts

to soften up then we'll go in with the rice. Now 
let's talk about the rice, okay. Risotto rice is

not everyday standard rice and there's all kinds 
of different varieties but basically it's short,

plump, and very creamy when you stir it. We're gonna 
go in with 400 grams of our lovely arborio rice.

So we're gonna let that toast for about one minute. 
Then we can go in, don't have to. We can go in with

some booze. So I'm gonna use some nice Italian 
white wine. So get the wine in and cook it away.

And now we're into the next part of the ritual... 
adding the stock. So I've got some nice stock here,

chicken stock. You can of course use veggie stock 
or any stock you like really. So one ladle at a

time and we give it a little love. And every single 
time the stock cooks away then you go back in with

another one and slowly but surely you'll start to 
see the rice change. This rice is gonna swell up

and almost quadruple in size. Okay... so while that 
rice carries on cooking, let's talk about cheese.

Now most risottos will have somewhere, parmesan. 
So you want a nice little handful of parmesan,

like that. And then let's talk about the goat's 
cheese. What I like is something that's tangy,

fresh and crumbly. You know what you can do is 
either get the tip of your knife and just kind

of get little nuggets of it or you can actually 
grate it as well. So from this you're going to

get a tang, you're going to get a freshness. So 
if you look in the pan now you can see how the

stock has pretty much cooked away so we'll carry 
on adding that beautiful stock. Stir it back in

again. Really, really nice. So the rice is going to 
take about 20 minutes to cook. And I want to show

you the next ingredient which is frozen peas. It's 
a really great ingredient. Let's get a nice little

handful or two. You're gonna get that little burst 
of sweetness and with the saltiness from the

goat's cheese and the smokiness from the bacon, 
it's gonna be joyful. So straight in they go. So

last I reckon, last ladle of stock goes in. So the 
risotto is nearly there but I know that when I add

this goat's cheese and parmesan, it's going to take 
it to the next level. I'm going to add a nice knob

of butter and I'm now going to turn the heat off, 
right. We don't want to be boiling cheese or butter.

I'm literally beating the cheese into this risotto. 
It smells amazing. The lid goes on top and we leave

it for one minute and then we serve it. And by 
leaving it, it just kind of relaxes the whole thing,

flavours, texture, it just does nice things. So 
remember we're looking for that ooze. So when

you put it in the middle of the plate, it just 
moves. Just lovely. Just a few little bits of

goat's cheese... you know just to make it pop. You can 
go back to the thyme and just steal a couple of the

tips of the thyme. That is my smoky bacon, sweet 
pea and goat cheese risotto. Let's have a try.

The tang of the goat's cheese, the sweetness 
of the little pops of peas, it's a really

elegant dish. There you go guys, that is 
the mighty risotto. Get cooking and enjoy
